courseDescription: Laboratory techniques in the diagnosis of clinically relevant microorganisms.
A fundamental course in microbiology that includes bacterial growth, synthesis, differentiation, microbial nutrition and metabolism.
A comprehensive survey of bacteria, including colonial morphology, cultural characteristics, biochemical identification, pathogenicity, epidemiology, and treatment.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and analysis of bacterial epidemiology

courseDescription: A study of the chemical, physical and microscopic analysis of human urine and other body fluids, with abnormal results interpreted and correlated to disease processes and cancer cytology of the urinary tract.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of urinary tract cancer cytology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Correlating abnormal results to disease processes
Identifying signs of urinary tract cancer

courseDescription: The study of the principles of the formation and development of blood, including the interpretation of normal and abnormal blood morphology and diagnostic procedures in the investigation of hematological disorders.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of blood formation and development principles
Interpretation of normal and abnormal blood morphology
Diagnostic procedures in investigating hematological disorders

courseDescription: Laboratory methods utilizing microscopy and other analytical procedures in the diagnosis and investigation of hematological disorders.
Laboratory experience in the chemical, physical, and microscopic examination of the urine and body fluids with emphasis on quality control, osmometry, and disease correlates.
Technical and Digital Skills: Chemical examination of urine and body fluids
Physical examination of urine and body fluids
Microscopic examination of urine and body fluids

courseDescription: Laboratory methods emphasizing isolation, identification and media requirements for pathogenic microorganisms.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and handling different growth media
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative work in a laboratory setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving when identification of pathogen is challenging

courseDescription: Laboratory methods in the procurement of blood by capillary, venipuncture and arterial draws, analytical variables, special phlebotomy tests, isolation techniques, safety, forensic, molecular, legal and ethical implications, pediatric, geriatric, and compromised patient concerns. All students must submit to venipuncture by fellow students.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Handling pediatric, geriatric, and compromised patients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding legal implications during blood collection

courseDescription: A 120-hour clinical internship for those desiring to qualify for the ASCP certification exam in phlebotomy.

This course covers the theory of operation of instrumentation used in the clinical chemistry laboratory. Methodologies discussed include: atomic absorption spectrometry, automation, blood gas instrumentation, chromatography, electrochemistry, electrophoresis, fluorometry, immunochemistry, luminometry, mass spectrometry, nephelometry, osmometry, POCT, spectrophotometry, and turbidimetry. Basic laboratory mathematics applicable to serial and compound dilutions, conversion between metric units, and determination of analyte concentration are presented.  Statistical applications for quality control data analysis are introduced.
Technical and Digital Skills: Operation of clinical chemistry laboratory instrumentation

courseDescription: A laboratory course designed for students entering the clinical laboratory field. The course includes the instrumental and data processing techniques required for the clinical analysis of body fluids, as well as statistical techniques applied to the interpretation of laboratory data, method comparison studies, quality control, calibration, maintenance, and troubleshooting of clinical chemistry analytics.

The study of the identification of blood group antigens and antibodies, standard testing procedures, decision criteria for component selection, and regulations of blood banks and transfusion services.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identification of blood group antigens and antibodies
Understanding regulations of blood banks and transfusion services
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating decision criteria for component selection
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Determining appropriate component selection based on testing results

courseDescription: The study of the body's immune response, its cellular and non-cellular components, in-vitro manifestations, diagnostic techniques and interpretations related to the investigation and diagnosis of infectious and non-infectious disease states.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the body's immune response
Knowledge of cellular and non-cellular components
Interpretation of investigations related to infectious and non-infectious disease states
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with medical professionals for disease diagnosis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Abilities to identify and diagnose infectious and non-infectious disease states
Analytical skills for interpreting cellular and non-cellular components investigations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Prioritize investigations based on severity of disease states

courseDescription: Laboratory methods emphasizing in-vitro antigen and antibody reactions used to aid in the diagnosis of infectious and non-infectious disorders.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identification of infectious and non-infectious disorders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of antigen and antibody reactions
Differential diagnosis of infectious and non-infectious disorders

courseDescription: Laboratory methods emphasizing procedures that lead to the identification of blood group antigens and antibodies and the selection of therapeutic components necessary for making transfusion-related decisions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Procedures for blood group antigen identification
Procedures for blood group antibody identification
Selection of therapeutic components for transfusion

courseDescription: Laboratory methods emphasizing the identification of medically relevant parasites and fungi.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Differential diagnosis of parasitic and fungal infections

courseDescription: A study of the medically important parasites, fungi, and viruses, and their medical significance.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of significant fungi and viruses
Ability to use medical reference databases
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex medical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing patterns and trends in parasitic, fungal, and viral infections
Identifying medical significance of various organisms

courseDescription: An introduction to the applications of biochemistry and clinical testing in the diagnosis of human disease. Practice given in the interpretation of laboratory data in the areas of carbohydrate, protein, lipid, genetic disorders, liver, renal, pancreatic, G.I., enzymatic, and cardiac testing. Also enzyme kinetics, electrolytes, acid base physiology, tumor markers, endocrinology, pharmacokinetics, therapeutic drug monitoring, and molecular diagnostics. Special emphasis on specimen collecting, pre- and post-analytical variables, and case studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of biochemical tests and procedures
Understanding of electrolytes and acid base physiology
Knowledge on tumor markers, endocrinology, pharmacokinetics, therapeutic drug monitoring, and molecular diagnostics
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Teamwork in a clinical laboratory setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of pre- and post-analytical variables
Solving complex problems related to human disease diagnosis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of laboratory data and records
Understanding and complying with standard lab safety and procedure guidelines

courseDescription: This course is an overview of general disease processes and causes in the human. All body systems will be covered including respiratory, gastrointestinal, circulatory, nervous, reproductive, and urinary. Aging, dietary, and stress factors will be discussed in the disease process. Bacteria, fungi, and viruses will be discussed in general and for each body system. Neoplasms will be covered for each body site. This course will be of benefit to anyone interested in diseases of the human body or entering the medical field. (cross listed with CYTO 404) Pre- or
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of disease processes and causes
Knowledge of different body systems including respiratory, gastrointestinal, circulatory, nervous, reproductive, and urinary
Understanding of impact of aging, dietary, and stress factors on disease process
Knowledge of bacteria, fungi, and viruses both in general and in relation to each body system
Understanding of neoplasms in various body sites
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to evaluate the impact of various factors on the disease process
Analytical skills to understand the interaction of different body systems and diseases
Problem-solving skills for understanding complex disease processes

courseDescription: A brief review of nucleic acid chemistry, followed by discussion of clinical applications of FDA approved assays used to detect pathogens for which testing algorithms include molecular based testing.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to detect pathogens using molecular based testing
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss clinical applications of assays
Ability to communicate complex scientific concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying appropriate assays for detecting specific pathogens

courseDescription: A course concerned with organization and management in the clinical setting including personnel supervision, planning, equipment justification, quality assurance, data processing, budgeting, fiscal techniques, marketing, regulatory agencies, educational methodologies, current issues, as well as legal and ethical considerations. This is a writing intensive course.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization and management in the clinical setting

courseDescription: Direct clinical experience offered in automated and manual hematology procedures used in distinguishing blood dyscrasias and coagulation abnormalities. (qualifies as a CAP experience)
Direct clinical experience offered in isolating and identifying human pathogens such as bacteria, fungi, and parasites from various clinical specimens.

courseTitle: Statistical Applications and Data Analysis in the Clinical Laboratory
courseDescription: Topics include review of basic statistics used in the laboratory; use of statistics for quality control, reference range determination, method comparisons, test utility assessment, techniques for searching the literature and assessing quality and applicability of published studies; and data organization and retrieval via queries. Students will perform projects, preferably using actual laboratory data, that relate to lecture topics.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing quality and applicability of published studies

courseDescription: Demonstration of stated clinical laboratory competencies within the discipline of hematology.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ensuring quality control in hematology testing

courseDescription: Demonstration of stated clinical laboratory competencies within the discipline of clinical chemistry.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interdisciplinary collaboration in a clinical setting

courseDescription: Demonstration of stated clinical laboratory competencies in the discipline of blood banking.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Team collaboration in a clinical setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving in blood banking procedures

courseDescription: Direct clinical experience offered in automated and manual clinical chemistry determinations with emphasis on the principles, instrumentation, interpretation, and diagnostic significance.
Direct clinical experience offered in the theories and principles of blood banking with emphasis on the instruction of technical procedures used in an AABB approved blood bank.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of blood bank theories and principles
Proficiency in AABB approved technical procedures
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate technical procedures effectively
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting technical issues in blood bank operations

courseDescription: In-depth review for Medical Laboratory Scientist (MLS) certification exam.

courseTitle: Special Topics in Medical Laboratory Science
courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics within the medical field.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Quality control in a medical laboratory

courseTitle: Directed Study in Medical Laboratory Science
courseDescription: Supervised experience in medical laboratory science specialties, allowing students to pursue areas of interest under faculty direction.

courseTitle: Directed Research in Medical Laboratory Science
courseDescription: Supervised research on a specific problem in Medical Laboratory Science. Regular meetings with faculty and a written/oral report are required.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solution development for medical laboratory problems

courseDescription: A course concerned with organization and management in the clinical setting including personnel supervision, planning, equipment justification, quality assurance, data processing, budgeting, fiscal techniques, marketing, regulatory agencies, educational methodologies, current issues, as well as legal and ethical considerations.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding legal and ethical considerations in a clinical setting

courseTitle: Statistical Applications and Data Analysis in the Clinical Laboratory
courseDescription: Topics include review of basic statistics used in the laboratory; use of statistics for quality control, reference range determination, method comparisons, test utility assessment, techniques for searching the literature and assessing quality and applicability of published studies; and data organization and retrieval via queries. Students will perform projects, preferably using actual laboratory data, that relate to lecture topics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of statistics for quality control
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing quality and applicability of published studies
Performing projects related to lecture topics
